stem: A 19-year-old client with a comminuted femur fracture is 24 hours post-injury. Based on the documentation in the Orthopedic-Pulmonary Surveillance Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute respiratory and neurological decline in a trauma patient.
Background: Femur fracture from high-velocity impact. Traction applied.
Assessment: Client is increasingly confused and 'combative.' Oxygen levels are dropping despite 4L NC.
Recommendation: Stabilization for Fat Embolism Syndrome.

tabs.title: Orthopedic & Pulmonary Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Skin ExamFine, red petechial rash over chest and axillaHallmark Sign
Mental StatusRestless; Disoriented to placeCerebral Embolization
Chest X-ray'Snowstorm' infiltrates notedAcute Lung Injury
Oxygen Saturation84% (Critical)Hypoxemia

actionOptions.text: Administer high-flow Oxygen via non-rebreather mask
Ensure strict immobilization of the fractured extremity
Administer IV Heparin to dissolve the fat globules
Instruct the client to perform leg exercises to prevent stagnation

parameterOptions.text: Respiratory rate, SpO2, and lung sounds (Snowstorm check)
Neurological status and Presence of Petechiae (Rash inspection)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign

rationale.correct: This is Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) (c2), which occurs in ~1–3% of long-bone fractures (like the femur). The 'Classic Triad' is present here: Respiratory distress (SpO2 84%), Neurological decline (Confusion), and the hallmark Petechial Rash (on the chest/axilla). Priority actions are supportive oxygenation (a1) and minimizing further fat 'leaking' from the marrow by keeping the bone immobilized (a2). Monitoring focuses on pulmonary function (p1) and neurological/skin trends (p2).
clinicalPearls: FES typically occurs 24–72 hours after the fracture.
Heparin and Corticosteroids are NOT proven effective; treatment is primarily supportive until the body clears the fat.
The 'Snowstorm' pattern on CXR represents the inflammatory reaction of the lungs to the free fatty acids released by the emboli.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking this is a standard PE and choosing Heparin.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Heparin works on BLOOD CLOTS. It does not dissolve fat. If the patient has a broken bone and a PETECHIAL RASH, it's FES, not a standard DVT-induced PE.

mnemonic.title: FES Triad
mnemonic.expansion: F-Fat in Lungs (Dyspnea). E-Emergency Head (Confusion). S-Skin Spots (Petechiae).
